data.simplified_title: Embryo implantation and Placental Development
data.source_system: Implantation of an embryo into the uterus & development of a functional placenta are critical to initiate & continue a pregnancy. Implantation failure causes infertility and is a major bottle-neck in IVF. Placental insufficiency leads to pregnancy loss, under-developed fetuses & a life-threatening pregnancy-specific disease preeclampsia. This application will investigate how a woman�s uterus works for implantation and placental development, how to increase IVF success and diagnose & potentially treat preeclampsia.

children.name: HIV latency and regulation of HIV life cycle.

data.scientific_title: HIV latency and regulation of HIV life cycle.
data.simplified_title: Cell interactions producing HIV latency
data.source_system: Current anti-HIV therapies can't cure HIV because HIV remains silent(latent) in long-lived cells. The HIV life cycle and virus production is linked to activation of the host cell, which is regulated by dendritic cells. This grant will explore how the factors controlling T cell activation and proliferation control virus expression and latency. By understanding how latent infection is established and maintained, these studies will potentially identify new ways to eliminate HIV infection.

children.name: Developing Relaxin Peptides as Novel Therapies for Fibrosis

data.scientific_title: Developing Relaxin Peptides as Novel Therapies for Fibrosis
data.simplified_title: Developing Novel Therapies for Fibrosis
data.source_system: I am a matrix biologist determining the molecular mechanisms and novel therapeutic targets for fibrosis (tissue scarring). In particular, my research, which has a strong translational focus, is involved with elucidating the anti-fibrotic potential of the relaxin peptide-hormones (either alone or as an adjunct therapies to existing/other novel treatments) _ as a means of developing therapeutic strategies for the treatment of cardiac and renal fibrosis.

children.name: Work-related road traffic injury: managing the risk

data.scientific_title: Work-related road traffic injury: managing the risk
data.field_of_research: Public Health and Health Services not elsewhere classified
data.simplified_title: Reducing work-related road trauma
data.source_system: Almost one third of registered motor vehicles in Australia are used for work purposes, the implications of this research namely, estimating the magnitude and identifying organisational determinants associated with work-related road traffic injury are substantial. Interventions arising from the findings of this research will contribute significantly to reductions in work-related road traffic injury and will support the National Road Safety Strategy target of a 30% reduction in serious injuries by 2030.

children.name: Targeting small airways to overcome resistance to therapy in asthma

data.scientific_title: Targeting small airways to overcome resistance to therapy in asthma
data.simplified_title: Targeting small airways to overcome resistance to therapy in asthma
data.source_system: There is a pressing need to overcome resistance to current therapies for severe asthma. Targetting inflammation-induced changes in small airway contraction offers an alternative strategy. We have identified a novel bronchodilator that relaxes maximally contracted mouse small airways when current treatment is ineffective. We will demonstrate its efficacy in animal models mimicking key features of human asthma, and define new ways to improve outcomes in poorly-controlled asthma.

children.name: Understanding mitochondrial DNA segregation and transmission.

data.scientific_title: Understanding mitochondrial DNA segregation and transmission.
data.simplified_title: Understanding mitochondrial DNA and inheritance.
data.source_system: We inherit our mitochondrial DNA from our mothers. Mutations to mitochondrial DNA can give rise to severely debilitating diseases that can be passed from one generation to the next. The aims of this application are to understand how mutant mitochondrial DNA is selected for; when it affects energy production during development; and to ensure that certain reproductive strategies do not result in the adverse transmission of mitochondrial DNA that will affect subsequent generations.

children.name: M2 macrophage polarization as a cause of vascular fibrosis and stiffening in hypertension

data.scientific_title: M2 macrophage polarization as a cause of vascular fibrosis and stiffening in hypertension
data.simplified_title: Macrophages and vascular stiffening
data.source_system: Blood vessel stiffening is a hallmark of hypertension (A.K.A. high blood pressure) and is thought to be a major contributor to the clinical complications of the condition, which include heart failure, stroke and renal impairment. Here we will test the novel concept that this stiffening process is caused by certain types of white blood cells (macrophages), which enter the walls of blood vessels and signal the surrounding cells to produce a rigid scaffolding protein called collagen.

children.name: Centre of Research Excellence for Patient Blood Management in Critical Illness and Trauma

data.scientific_title: Centre of Research Excellence for Patient Blood Management in Critical Illness and Trauma
data.simplified_title: Centre of Research Excellence for Patient Blood Management in Critical Illness and Trauma
data.source_system: Blood transfusion is area of major public interest. In critically ill or major trauma patients it can both be life-saving and dangerous. There is continuing uncertainty about how best to use blood and blood products in such patients. The Centre of Research Excellence for Patient Blood Management in Critical Illness and Trauma will undertake vital research to improve our understanding of the effects of transfusion on patient outcomes and how to best manage this vital community resource.

children.name: Improving the control of hypertension in rural India: Overcoming the barriers to diagnosis and effective treatment

data.scientific_title: Improving the control of hypertension in rural India: Overcoming the barriers to diagnosis and effective treatment
data.field_of_research: Public Health and Health Services not elsewhere classified
data.simplified_title: Improving the control of hypertension in rural India: Overcoming the barriers to diagnosis and effective treatment
data.sub_type: GACD - Implementation Research on Hypertension in Low & Middle Income Countries
data.source_system: We know little about barriers to the control of high blood pressure in rural regions of low income countries. These rural areas differ in the proportion of people with high blood pressure, the risk factors for high blood pressure and most likely the barriers to good treatment of blood pressure. We aim to find out what these barriers are, and develop and test a program that can be used to improve control of high blood pressure in very diverse settings.

children.name: The National Notifiable Diseases Surveillance System, 1991-2011: Epidemiologic Analysis of the First 20 Years of National Infectious Diseases Notifications in Australia

data.scientific_title: The National Notifiable Diseases Surveillance System, 1991-2011: Epidemiologic Analysis of the First 20 Years of National Infectious Diseases Notifications in Australia
data.simplified_title: The National Notifiable Diseases Surveillance System, 1991-2011: Analysis of the First 20 Years of Australian Infectious Disease Notification Data
data.source_system: The National Notifiable Diseases Surveillance System contains approximately 4 million records of infectious disease notifications made since 1991. We will use these data to describe trends in notifiable infectious diseases in Australia, determine the impact of interventions such as immunisation, and develop algorithms to identify infectious disease outbreaks as early as possible. This information will be used to help minimise the burden of infectious diseases in Australia in the future.

children.name: A prospective, randomised, double-blind trial of extended- versus bolus-infusion _-lactam therapy in infective exacerbations of cystic fibrosis

data.scientific_title: A prospective, randomised, double-blind trial of extended- versus bolus-infusion _-lactam therapy in infective exacerbations of cystic fibrosis
data.simplified_title: Comparison of extended-infusion versus bolus-infusion of antibiotics for treatment of respiratory infections in patients with cystic fibrosis
data.source_system: I am an infectious diseases physician focused on the most effective way to use antibiotics to treat infections. People with cystic fibrosis often get lung infections and the bacteria that causes this, Pseudomonas aeruginosa, can be difficult to treat. I will be investigating whether infusing antibiotics over a prolonged period of time is more effective than standard therapy in treatment of Pseudomonas aeruginosa lung infections in patients with cystic fibrosis.

children.name: Does dietary modulation of the colonic microflora attenuate the effects of advanced glycation endproducts?

data.scientific_title: Does dietary modulation of the colonic microflora attenuate the effects of advanced glycation endproducts?
data.simplified_title: Modifying gut bacteria with dietary supplements to prevent or slow the development of type 2 diabetes.
data.source_system: Advanced glycation endproducts (AGEs) occur naturally in the human body, and also enter our bodies from cigarette smoking and eating heat-processed foods. Too many AGEs in the body can damage blood vessels and contribute to the development of diabetes. Changing the types of bacteria which live in the human bowel may prevent or slow diabetes development. This project aims to determine whether dietary supplements which increase beneficial bacteria in the bowel can reduce AGE levels and their negative effects.

children.name: The significance of aeroallergens in Eosinophilic esophagitis

data.scientific_title: The significance of aeroallergens in Eosinophilic esophagitis
data.simplified_title: The significance of aeroallergens in Eosinophilic esophagitis
data.source_system: Eosinophilic esophagitis is an allergic condition that causes difficulty swallowing food and chest discomfort.Current diagnostic methods are inaccurate, and treatments are not curative. This project aims to clarify the role of promising new diagnostic techniques and to delineate the  significance of aeroallergens (e.g. pollens) with a view to improving  the treatment of eosinophilc esophagitis in the future. It is possible that simply avoiding pollens or treating hayfever in the future may be all that is required to manage this condition.

data.scientific_title: Development of new antivirals.
data.simplified_title: Development of new antivirals.
data.source_system: Despite recent advances in therapeutic options, chronic viral infections, including infection with hepatitis C virus and hepatitis B virus, continue to be a significant cause of morbidity and mortality in Australia and affecting hundreds of millions of people  worldwide. This R&D program aims to develop a cheaper drug formulation that is easier to deliver and more stable for transport to remote areas.

children.name: Effect of cross-linking cytokines to natural and synthetic matrices on post-implantation fibrosis in animal models

data.scientific_title: Effect of cross-linking cytokines to natural and synthetic matrices on post-implantation fibrosis in animal models
data.field_of_research: Medical and Health Sciences not elsewhere classified
data.simplified_title: Do surgical implants treated with follistatin reduce fibrosis, scarring and inflammation in implanted synthetic and natural matrices in mice?
data.source_system: My research will focus on the development and in vivo testing of cytokine cross-linked surgical implant materials in selected mouse and rat models. We hypothesise that Follistatin bound to heparin sulphate cross-linked natural and synthetic matrix implants will suppress the formation of Extra cellular matrix around the implant during wound healing in a mouse surgical model.

children.name: Gene Therapy and Bone Marrow transplantation for treatment of experimental autoimmune uveitis

data.scientific_title: Gene Therapy and Bone Marrow transplantation for treatment of experimental autoimmune uveitis
data.simplified_title: Genetically modified bone marrow treatment for  uveitis
data.source_system: Bone marrow stem cells modified to express self antigen is proposed as a treatment for experimental autoimmune uveitis. A major goal of this research is to investigate the impact and possible mechanism of gene therapy on the development and progression of autoimmune disease in the eye to prevent or reduce the severity of disease.

children.name: Polypharmacy in the heart failure patient: are all prescribed drug classes required?

data.scientific_title: Polypharmacy in the heart failure patient: are all prescribed drug classes required?
data.simplified_title: Polypharmacy in heart failure
data.source_system: This project investigates the issue of polypharmacy is heart failure. Polypharmacy is the use of four or more prescription medications, and heart failure patients take six on average. This project investigates the evidence for safe withdrawal of medications failure that have not been shown to prolong life in heart, doctor and patient attitudes to withdrawing medications, and then runs a series of three clinical trials, each withdrawing a different medication in heart failure patients and closely monitors the effects.

children.name: A brief couple-focused psycho-educational intervention to prevent postnatal mental health problems in women: a cluster randomised trial

data.scientific_title: A brief couple-focused psycho-educational intervention to prevent postnatal mental health problems in women: a cluster randomised trial
data.simplified_title: Preventing postnatal mental health problems in women.
data.source_system: Preventing weight gain in those currently of normal weight, as well as those who are overweight, is a national and global health priority. Weight gain in women of reproductive age is associated with sub-fertility and metabolic diseases. Women in rural areas are at high risk, as they tend to gain weight at a higher rate and to have less access to services than their urban counterparts.  This study will adapt and test a successful gain intervention (HeLP-her) in women living in small rural areas

children.name: Aberrant T helper cells in autoimmune diseases

data.scientific_title: Aberrant T helper cells in autoimmune diseases
data.simplified_title: Aberrant T helper cells in autoimmune diseases
data.source_system: An estimated 5 million patients worldwide suffer from the autoimmune disease and in Australia and New zealand, autoimmune diseases affect around 1 in 20 people.Our research will investigate patients samples and animal models to identify the pathogenesis of autoimmune disease and establish new monitor systems and better therapeutic treatments of autoimmune diseases.

children.name: In vivo studies on ventriculo-vascular coupling and the role of aortic pressure wave morphology on coronary blood flow

data.scientific_title: In vivo studies on ventriculo-vascular coupling and the role of aortic pressure wave morphology on coronary blood flow
data.simplified_title: Studies into the relationships between coronary blood flow, the heart and aortic pressure
data.source_system: Heart disease is a leading cause of death and disability in Australia. Conditions resulting in reduced blood flow to the heart are particularly common and dangerous. Despite significant progress, we still do not understand exactly how changes in heart function and the aorta (the major artery arising from the heart) affect blood flow to the heart. This study will utilise sophisticated new techniques to look at the interactions between heart function, pressure in the aorta and coronary blood flow

children.name: The mechanism and application of a superagonistic antibody for human IL-21.

data.scientific_title: The mechanism and application of a superagonistic antibody for human IL-21.
data.simplified_title: The mechanism and application of a superagonistic antibody for human IL-21.
data.source_system: Monoclonal antibodies are widely used in diagnosis and therapy due to their outstanding specificity and safety. The monoclonal antibodies recognizing cytokines with enhancing functions are an emerging class of novel reagents in immunotherapy. This project is to investigate how a newly indentified monoclonal antibody enhances the activity of a cytokine and use this immunostimulatory function to design new strategies for better vaccination and treatment for cancer and infection.

children.name: The role of stellate cells in fibrosis and liver disease progression in HIV-Hepatitis B co-infection

data.scientific_title: The role of stellate cells in fibrosis and liver disease progression in HIV-Hepatitis B co-infection
data.simplified_title: Dissecting mechanisms of liver disease progression in HIV-Hepatitis B co-infection
data.source_system: Liver related mortality is the commonest cause of non-AIDS death in HIV infected individuals on treatment. With HIV, HBV liver damage is accelerated and liver-related mortality increased. Understanding how and why is critical to management. I will examine the role of hepatic stellate cells using in vitro models and directly ex vivo from infected patient biopsy tissue. I will investigate the activated of these cells by HIV and HBV infection, thus promoting scar formation with liver injury.

children.name: Polycystic ovary syndrome, insulin resistance and obesity

data.scientific_title: Polycystic ovary syndrome, insulin resistance and obesity
data.simplified_title: Polycystic ovary syndrome, insulin resistance and obesity
data.source_system: Research to be undertaken will focus on the impact of excess weight on insulin action in polycystic ovary syndrome (PCOS). PCOS is the most common hormone condition in women of reproductive age, with significant long-term health implications. Identification of key metabolic and lifestyle associated factors in PCOS and the long term impact of these on health outcomes will assist in enabling earlier detection and intervention to optimise management and minimise long-term sequelae.

data.scientific_title: 2011 Equipment Grant
data.simplified_title: 2011 Equipment Grant

children.name: Development of an effective therapy for Cheyne-Stokes breathing in Heart Failure.

data.scientific_title: Development of an effective therapy for Cheyne-Stokes breathing in Heart Failure.
data.simplified_title: Treatment of sleep disordered breathing in patients with heart failure.
data.source_system: During sleep, patients with heart failure often exhibit a cyclic pattern of breathing in which a period of regular breathing alternates with a period when breathing ceases. This breathing pattern is associated with increased mortality and reduced quality of life but to date no effective treatment for it exists. We have developed a method to calculate an exact level of carbon dioxide to stabilise breathing in each individual, offering the prospect of a better night�s sleep and a longer life.

children.name: Renal Programming Effects of Maternal Obesity

data.scientific_title: Renal Programming Effects of Maternal Obesity
data.simplified_title: The impact of maternal obesity on the developing kidney
data.source_system: The prevalence of maternal obesity is alarmingly high in Australia and the western world.  However, there is little understanding of how obesity of the mother affects the development of the kidney of the fetus and, in turn, how this affects the risk of these offspring developing cardiovascular and renal disease in adulthood.  I hope to address the gaps in this knowledge in my studies. This information is critical in order to develop appropriate health care to those born to obese mothers.

children.name: Clinical and physiological features of obstructive sleep apnoea phenotypes

data.scientific_title: Clinical and physiological features of obstructive sleep apnoea phenotypes
data.simplified_title: Phenotypes of obstructive sleep apnoea
data.source_system: Obstructive sleep apnoea has variable causes and clinical effects in different patient groups. My research will quantify the contribution of various physiological processes to the development of upper airway obstruction in different sub-types of sleep apnoea and to determine how this affects clinical presentation.  I will be measuring a number of physiological parameters, and finding out how sleep apnoea manifests in terms of symptomatology and adverse health effects.

children.name: Understanding and preventing chronic disease in people living with HIV

data.scientific_title: Understanding and preventing chronic disease in people living with HIV
data.simplified_title: Chronic disease in people with HIV
data.source_system: Australia�s ageing population is increasingly at risk of chronic diseases such as heart disease and diabetes. For Australians who are living with HIV, these diseases occur more frequently and at an earlier age. I will be investigating the underlying reasons for this increase in risk and will test innovative online systems that help people living with HIV reduce their risk of chronic disease. This work will provide important information for Australians at risk of developing chronic disease.

children.name: Further Development, Evaluation and Dissemination of the Chinese Peers for Progress Diabetes Program

data.scientific_title: Further Development, Evaluation and Dissemination of the Chinese Peers for Progress Diabetes Program
data.field_of_research: Public Health and Health Services not elsewhere classified
data.simplified_title: Applying peer support approach for diabetes prevention and management in Chinese community settings
data.source_system: This research will train diabetes patients who are becoming volunteer peer leaders (who lead face-to face peer group meetings and activities to help group members) in effective management of key self-care behaviors, which include taking prescribed medications, following diet and exercise regimens, blood glycemic self-monitoring, and coping emotionally with the rigors of living with diabetes.

children.name: The role of sterols in amyloid toxicity

data.scientific_title: The role of sterols in amyloid toxicity
data.field_of_research: Biochemistry and Cell Biology not elsewhere classified
data.simplified_title: Understanding the relationship between cellular sterols and amyloid toxicity that occurs in many neurodegenerative diseases
data.source_system: Alzheimer's, Huntington's and Parkinson's diseases involve the formation of protein aggregates, termed amyloid. The formation of amyloid leads to cell death and neurodegeneration. The most important cellular events perturbed by the formation of amyloid aggregates are unclear. Recent evidence suggests that sterols (including cholesterol) have an important role in cellular toxicity. This study will examine the molecular basis for this, enhancing our understanding of the amyloid diseases and could suggest novel therapeutic avenues.

data.scientific_title: Australia Fellowship
data.simplified_title: Australia Fellowship

children.name: Molecular characterisation of host cell targets of human pathogenic viruses and evaluating their potential as novel therapeutic targets.

data.scientific_title: Molecular characterisation of host cell targets of human pathogenic viruses and evaluating their potential as novel therapeutic targets.
data.simplified_title: New Targets for Antiviral Therapies
data.source_system: There are currently no therapeutics to treat victims of Hendra, Nipah or Rabies virus infections, which account for > 50,000 deaths/yr worldwide. Through not fully understood mechanisms, these viruses affect the functions of specific cellular proteins in order to inhibit the host immune system, a process essential to their pathogenicity. We aim to characterise the mechanisms underlying viral inhibition of host immunity and evaluate their potential as novel targets to develop urgently needed therapeutics against these deadly pathogens.

children.name: Optimisation of Wolbachia based control strategies to reduce dengue incidence and disease

data.scientific_title: Optimisation of Wolbachia based control strategies to reduce dengue incidence and disease
data.simplified_title: Optimisation of Wolbachia based control strategies to reduce dengue incidence and disease
data.source_system: The project will build on recent advances in the use of Wolbachia infected mosquitoes to limit dengue transmission. Key outcomes will include improved understanding of Wolbachia spread after release, development of techniques for regional spread, understanding the epidemiology of dengue transmission in Vietnam and preparing a panel of new Wolbachia:A. aegypti strain combinations for evaluation for implementation programs.

children.name: Dissecting the molecular mechanisms during reprogramming of different somatic cells into induced pluripotent stem cells and the plasticity potential of  their intermediate stages.

data.scientific_title: Dissecting the molecular mechanisms during reprogramming of different somatic cells into induced pluripotent stem cells and the plasticity potential of  their intermediate stages.
data.simplified_title: Determining the events that occur during the reprogramming of different adult cells into embryonic stem-like cells and the capacity of  becoming another specific adult cell during this process.
data.source_system: I am a biochemist interested in the molecular mechanisms involved in gene expression and how these processes govern cell identity.  I use a combination of mouse models, biochemical techniques and bioinformatics to study the �reprogramming� of adult cells into embryonic stem-like cells and how this technology can be used to generate different cell types for use in cellular replacement therapies and drug screening.

children.name: Epistatic and cross-tissue analysis for human gene expression traits

data.scientific_title: Epistatic and cross-tissue analysis for human gene expression traits
data.simplified_title: Revealing how interactions and mutation patterns among genes change in different human tissues by bioinformatics tools
data.source_system: Our understanding of common disease is hampered by the complexity of the human system. The DNA variations found in genome wide association studies of common disease are rarely in the gene coding region. I aim to develop statistical bioinformatic tools to find how the DNA variations affect human disease by taking gene expression as the quantitative phenotype. The results will explain the genetic risk of human common disease, so that better personalized prevention and therapy can be achieved.

children.name: Deep Brain Stimulation for Treatment Resistant Major Depression: Neural Correlates and Neuropsychological Outcomes

data.scientific_title: Deep Brain Stimulation for Treatment Resistant Major Depression: Neural Correlates and Neuropsychological Outcomes
data.simplified_title: Deep Brain Stimulation: Investigating a Novel Therapeutic Approach to Depression
data.source_system: Major depression is a prevalent and devastating mental illness. While there are numerous pharmacological and psychological antidepressant therapies available, many patients do not respond to these treatments. Deep Brain Stimulation (DBS) is emerging as a potential treatment option for individuals with chronic severe treatment resistant major depression. The current project will investigate the cognitive and neurobiological outcomes associated with the use of DBS to treat depression.

children.name: Effects of medical pluralism and cross-border drug flows on the health-seeking behaviour of Indian-Australians and Anglo-Australians with depression

data.scientific_title: Effects of medical pluralism and cross-border drug flows on the health-seeking behaviour of Indian-Australians and Anglo-Australians with depression
data.simplified_title: Medical pluralism and health-seeking among Indian-Australians and Anglo-Australians with depression
data.source_system: Taking medication for depression varies by cultural groups. This project will examine how Indian-Australians and Anglo-Australians access and use antidepressant treatments from biomedicine and complementary and alternative medicine. The project looks at the effects of these medicines and treatments on the body and wellbeing and how some treatments could be integrated to deliver more holistic and culturally sensitive forms of care.

children.name: Cardiac function in the growth restricted fetus: the effects of betamethasone and melatonin

data.scientific_title: Cardiac function in the growth restricted fetus: the effects of betamethasone and melatonin
data.simplified_title: Mending the growth restricted fetal heart
data.source_system: I am an Obstetrician interested in the problems of growth-restricted babies. Devastatingly, many of these babies do not survive pregnancy and survivors face difficult challenges throughout their lifetime. My research uses the latest ultrasound technology to study their heart while still in the womb, evaluating if our current treatments are safe or possibly harmful, and finally testing melatonin as an antioxidant to protect their heart from damage they may sustain while still in the womb.

children.name: Synaesthesia for pain: Incidence and manifestation

data.scientific_title: Synaesthesia for pain: Incidence and manifestation
data.simplified_title: Empathy and personal experience of pain when seeing others in pain
data.source_system: I am a researcher interested in how we process pain in ourselves and others. I have identified a novel phenomenon whereby some individuals not only have empathy for others in pain, but experience pain in their own bodies when they see others in pain. I will further investigate these experiences to understand and highlight whether there are any distinct emotional, empathic, attentional or brain processes in people who experience empathic pain with a view to establishing appropriate treatment.

children.name: Recognition and interaction of virus by the innate immune system

data.scientific_title: Recognition and interaction of virus by the innate immune system
data.simplified_title: Innate immune defences following virus infection
data.source_system: The innate immune system acts rapidly to limit infection of invading pathogens. The interaction and recognition of pathogens such as viruses by the innate immune system, is of importance to understand why particular pathogens induce disease.

data.scientific_title: Cancer-Associated Fibroblast Stem Cells
data.simplified_title: Stem Cells in the Prostate Cancer Microenvironment
data.source_system: The interactions between tumour cells and their surroundings are critical in prostate cancer. This project seeks to be the first to characterise a new cell type in the prostate cancer microenvironment, �cancer-associated fibroblast stem cells�, which are a potential therapeutic target. This will consolidate and extend Dr Mitchell Lawrence�s significant expertise and a sustained record of contribution to prostate cancer research.

children.name: Structure and composition of the pre-T cell receptor-CD3 complex

data.scientific_title: Structure and composition of the pre-T cell receptor-CD3 complex
data.simplified_title: The mechanism responsible for quality control in the immune system
data.source_system: In order to recognize a wide variety of pathogens, humans produce many different T cell receptors (TCRs) by the process of gene-rearrangement. However, gene-rearrangement may not always lead to a functioning TCR. We are studying the pre-TCR protein that is responsible for monitoring the success of gene-rearrangement and is thus essential for the formation of a robust immune system. Understanding pre-TCR function will lead to new treatments for immune related diseases.

children.name: Investigating healing outcomes in people with venous ulcers: a randomised controlled trial

data.scientific_title: Investigating healing outcomes in people with venous ulcers: a randomised controlled trial
data.simplified_title: Investigating healing outcomes in people with venous ulcers
data.source_system: Venous leg ulcers (VLU) are an extremely common, debilitating, costly problem and the burden is expected to rise with the ageing population, obesity and diabetes. Standard best practice treatment includes compression bandaging of the lower leg by tight bandaging. Application of 3 layer (3L) tubular bandage appears to be a promising new treatment according to a pilot study. We will conduct a randomised controlled trial to investigate improvement in healing with 3L and to measure cost-effectiveness when compared to standard compression.

children.name: Neuro-protection in the Preterm Brain - A New Role for Dopamine Therapy?

data.scientific_title: Neuro-protection in the Preterm Brain - A New Role for Dopamine Therapy?
data.simplified_title: Neuro-protection in the Preterm Brain - A New Role for Dopamine Therapy?
data.source_system: Brain injury in premature babies leads to long term adverse outcome. Preliminary data show that dopamine improves brain oxygen. Our study will define effects of dopamine in preventing injury in the immature brain, using animal studies. In immature lambs receiving dopamine, we will test the protective effect of dopamine on brain oxygenation during hypoxia. Outcome will be measured by examining cell injury on lamb brain slices.

children.name: Aged Support and Aged Care: program and policy structures to support ageing well in rural and regional Australia

data.scientific_title: Aged Support and Aged Care: program and policy structures to support ageing well in rural and regional Australia
data.simplified_title: Aged Support and Aged Care: program and policy structures to support ageing well in rural and regional Australia
data.source_system: The current primary focus of aged care in Australia is on the frail aged and end of life care. This project is designed to utilise evidence from earlier research into rural and regional ageing and work with aged care providers and programs to broaden their focus to one that supports older Australians to remain active, included, engaged and contributing members of their families and communities, regardless of age.

children.name: Intensive care management and quality of survival of acute respiratory distress syndrome

data.scientific_title: Intensive care management and quality of survival of acute respiratory distress syndrome
data.simplified_title: ICU management and quality of survival of ARDS
data.source_system: Acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS) is a severe inflammatory condition of the lungs that complicates many critical illnesses and is associated with high mortality and morbidity. Although intensive care admission and mechanical ventilation provide life-saving support during ARDS, they can lead to poor long term outcome. The aim of this program is to compare the clinical efficiency of new strategies in ICU to that of current standard care and to improve the quality of survival of patients with ARDS.

children.name: Identification of novel PTH anabolic targets in osteoblasts

data.scientific_title: Identification of novel PTH anabolic targets in osteoblasts
data.field_of_research: Biochemistry and Cell Biology not elsewhere classified
data.simplified_title: New factors that build bone
data.source_system: Osteoporosis is a major disease affecting Australians.  Whilst there are a number of drugs available that will reduce bone loss, there are few drugs available that build new bone, and little is known of the action of these drugs.  New targets have been identified that modulate bone formation, and this project aims to validate these in appropriate models and determine their mechanism of action.

children.name: Systemic approaches of muscle stem cell quiescence and differentiation

data.scientific_title: Systemic approaches of muscle stem cell quiescence and differentiation
data.simplified_title: Project Grant Muscle Stem Cell Differentiation
data.source_system: In the repair of injured muscles, after physical exercise, as part of the ageing process, and in muscle disorders, activated muscle stem cells proliferate and differentiate to replace affected tissues. The aim of this project is to apply systemic, genome-wide approaches to identify the gene networks involved in the balance between the differentiation or the self-renewing state of muscle stem cells.

children.name: Systemic approaches of myoblast fusion in vertebrates

data.scientific_title: Systemic approaches of myoblast fusion in vertebrates
data.simplified_title: Project Grant Myoblast Fusion
data.source_system: Myoblast fusion is a poorly understood process of crucial importance during muscle growth and repair. Furthermore, engineered myoblasts can be introduced to fuse with mature muscles, forming a stable hybrid organ within the adults, thus offering novel therapeutic possibilities in the future. In this research, we will undertake the first systemic, genome-wide approach to identify and characterise the gene networks underlying muscle fusion in vertebrates.

children.name: SIGN receptors and the antiinflammatory activity of sialylated IgG Fcs

data.scientific_title: SIGN receptors and the antiinflammatory activity of sialylated IgG Fcs
data.simplified_title: Manipulation of antibodies to suppress harmful inflammation
data.source_system: IgG antibodies are a crucial component of the immune system, and significantly contribute  to  host  protection  against  cancer  and  infectious  diseases.    Additionally, therapeutic  IgG  antibodies  have  been  developed  for  treatment  of  cancer  and inflammatory diseases.  The studies proposed herein will elucidate one important aspect of how  IgG antibodies act as anti-inflammatory agents, and may  lead  to  the design of more effective IgG based therapies for the treatment of inflammatory diseases or cancer.

children.name: Brain ageing _ understanding the relationships between brain structure, gait, cognition and falls

data.scientific_title: Brain ageing _ understanding the relationships between brain structure, gait, cognition and falls
data.field_of_research: Medical and Health Sciences not elsewhere classified
data.simplified_title: Brain structure, gait, cognition and falls in older people
data.source_system: This fellowship will support novel population-based research directed at understanding how the ageing brain is associated with cognition and the control of gait in older people, and whether early gait changes are able to predict serious adverse outcomes such as future dementia and falls.  A better understanding of the relationship between the brain, cognition and mobility is crucial in the step towards successful ageing of older Australians.

children.name: THE ROLE OF THE TETRASPANINS CD37 AND CD82 IN LEUKOCYTE MIGRATION

data.scientific_title: THE ROLE OF THE TETRASPANINS CD37 AND CD82 IN LEUKOCYTE MIGRATION
data.simplified_title: CD37, CD82  and immune cell migration
data.source_system: White blood cells must be able to migrate to fight infection. For instance, immune responses are started by the migration of one type of white blood cells to the lymph node. Also, once activated white blood cells migrate out of the circulation to the site of infection where they can kill bacteria and viruses. This grant studies 2 proteins that control white blood cell migration. These proteins may one day be targets for drugs that either promote immunity or reduce inflammation.

children.name: Argonaute proteins in the mammalian antiviral response

data.scientific_title: Argonaute proteins in the mammalian antiviral response
data.simplified_title: Argonaute proteins in the mammalian antiviral response
data.source_system: Viruses are the most abundant infectious agents on earth, and the diseases caused by them are a constant threat and cause of mortality worldwide. Awarded the Nobel Prize for Medicine in 2006, RNA interference (RNAi) is a natural process that plants use to attack viruses. Humans possess all of the tools for RNAi, but whether it is used for antiviral defense is unknown. This study aims to uncover this immune process which will open new avenues to treat virus infections, such as influenza and HIV.

children.name: Dual inhibition of independent cell survival pathways as a new approach for targeting leukemic stem cells

data.scientific_title: Dual inhibition of independent cell survival pathways as a new approach for targeting leukemic stem cells
data.simplified_title: New approaches for targeting leukemic stem cells
data.source_system: While most leukemia patients initially respond well to chemotherapy, >60% die because the disease returns as a result of the survival of leukaemia cells following treatment. We have shown that targetting two enzymes, PI3K and Cdk9, with a drug called PIK75 potently and specifically kills leukemia cells by blocking their survival. We now seek to examine the therapeutic potential of our discovery with a view toward developing new targetted therapies in the future.

children.name: Enhanced nuclear transport in transformed cells; implications for cancer treatment

data.scientific_title: Enhanced nuclear transport in transformed cells; implications for cancer treatment
data.simplified_title: Enhanced nuclear transport in cancer cells
data.source_system: We have found that cancer cells are different to normal cells in terms of their ability to accumulate molecules in the cell nucleus. We intend to pursue this observation in detail, to understand the mechanism thereof, and the extent to which all types of cancer cells are similar in this regard. The results will have high relevance to understanding of oncogenesis, and of utility in approaches to anti-cancer therapies relying on the delivery of nuclear acting drugs.

children.name: Bile Acid and Neurosteroid Signaling to the Nervous System

data.scientific_title: Bile Acid and Neurosteroid Signaling to the Nervous System
data.simplified_title: Mechanisms of Defective Digestion and Sensation in Patients with Liver Diseases
data.source_system: Defects in the secretion of bile into the intestine cause digestive diseases, and abnormal circulating levels of bile acids induce profound itch and abnormal pain sensation. This project examines whether a cell-surface receptor (TGR5) produced by intestinal and sensory neurons mediates actions of bile acids on intestinal functions, itch and pain. The project will define mechanisms of digestive and sensory disorders and identify new therapies for constipation, diarrhoea, itch and pain.

children.name: Epigenetic regulation of core centromere CENP-A chromatin integrity

data.scientific_title: Epigenetic regulation of core centromere CENP-A chromatin integrity
data.simplified_title: Factors that control the establishment of centromere structure and function
data.source_system: A centromere is a region of DNA typically found near the middle of a chromosome where two identical sister chromatids come in contact. It is involved in cell division as the point of attachment to the mitotic spindle. Defective centromeres can result in genome instability, infertility and development of cancers. This work involves a study into how the identity of a centromere is maintained and inherited after each cell division. This has significant implication in the understanding of cell growth and cancer development.

children.name: Function of ATRX, H3.3 and PML nuclear bodies in the regulation of telomere chromatin integrity

data.scientific_title: Function of ATRX, H3.3 and PML nuclear bodies in the regulation of telomere chromatin integrity
data.simplified_title: Epigenetic factors that control the formation of telomere chromatin state
data.source_system: The telomere is required for protecting chromosome ends. During cell division and development, telomeres lose their repeats, exposing the chromosome ends to damage. The consequences of this damage are disease, cancer, and aging. By contrast, embryonic stem cells (ES) continually renew their telomeres and do not stop growing. ES cells thereby provide a means to unravel the molecular mechanisms of indefinite telomere renewal. Here we propose a novel mechanism that operates to control continual telomere renewal in ES cells.

children.name: Identification of critical factors for the establishment and maintenance of the epidermal barrier

data.scientific_title: Identification of critical factors for the establishment and maintenance of the epidermal barrier
data.field_of_research: Medical and Health Sciences not elsewhere classified
data.simplified_title: Formation and maintenance of the barrier function of the skin
data.source_system: The human skin plays a crucial role in the body�s defence against our hostile environment. The outer most layer of the skin, the epidermis is essential for formation and repair of the skin barrier. We have identified a family of genes that are pivotal for skin development and function. Disruption of these genes has disastrous consequences, including loss of barrier function and the development of skin cancers. This project examines how these diseases occur.

children.name: A novel genetic element controlling adult hemoglobin production

data.scientific_title: A novel genetic element controlling adult hemoglobin production
data.simplified_title: Understanding the control of adult blood production
data.source_system: Disorders of the blood protein hemoglobin are the commonest genetic diseases worldwide, and include thalassemia and sickle cell disease. In this proposal we study two novel mouse lines that exhibit thalassemia, but lack any of the known genetic mutations that cause this disease. These mice afford us the opportunity to make unique observations into how hemoglobin is produced, and thereby provide a platform for new therapeutic approaches in these devastating diseases of the blood.

children.name: Randomised Controlled Trial of Melatonin for Delayed Sleep Phase Disorder

data.scientific_title: Randomised Controlled Trial of Melatonin for Delayed Sleep Phase Disorder
data.simplified_title: Melatonin for Delayed Sleep Phase Disorder
data.source_system: Delayed Sleep Phase Disorder (DSPD) is a sleep disorder affecting 7-16% of adolescents and young adults. It is associated with poor health and impaired academic and social functioning. We will test in a randomised controlled trial whether the hormone melatonin can be used as a treatment for DSPD. We will also assess whether genetic factors are linked to treatment outcome. The study will provide a much-needed standardised diagnostic and treatment approach for DSPD.

children.name: Helicobacter pylori acquisition of host cholesterol: its role in inflammation

data.scientific_title: Helicobacter pylori acquisition of host cholesterol: its role in inflammation
data.simplified_title: The role of cholesterol in stomach disease due to Helicobacter pylori
data.source_system: The bacterium Helicobacter pylori is present in the stomach of half the world�s population.  It is estimated that 20% of these people will suffer from peptic ulcer disease, whereas as many as 1% will develop stomach cancer later in life. The common factor in all these diseases is the inflammation induced by the bacterium.   This project will investigate a new mechanism by which H. pylori causes inflammation and how dietary cholesterol may be involved in this process.

children.name: Hormonal regulation of NPY neurons in the arcuate nucleus of the hypothalamus

data.scientific_title: Hormonal regulation of NPY neurons in the arcuate nucleus of the hypothalamus
data.simplified_title: Hormonal regulation of appetite-activating cells in the brain
data.source_system: Obesity is a serious medical concern affecting the social, medical and economic capabilities within Australia. This proposal examines the hormonal regulation of cells in the brain inducing appetite. By understanding how these hormones influence appetite-inducing cells, we hope to identify effective targets to treat food intake and body weight gain.

data.scientific_title: Australian Resuscitation Outcomes Consortium [AUS-ROC] CRE
data.simplified_title: Australian Resuscitation Outcomes Consortium [AUS-ROC] CRE
data.source_system: The Australian Resuscitation Outcomes Consortium (Aus-ROC) will be modelled on  the highly successful North American Resuscitation Outcomes Consortium. The mission of Aus-ROC will be to conduct clinical trials and observational studies into the emergency management of out-of-hospital cardiopulmonary arrest.  Building on our existing collaborative partnerships, our goal is to improve patient outcomes and build the research capacity in prehospital emergency care.

children.name: The NF-kB transcription factors c-Rel and RelA control multiple steps in natural CD4 regulatory T cell development

data.scientific_title: The NF-kB transcription factors c-Rel and RelA control multiple steps in natural CD4 regulatory T cell development
data.simplified_title: NF-kB and regulatory T cell development
data.source_system: An unfortunate consequence of immune function is that occasionally rogue immune cells are produced that attack the host and lead to the development of so-called autoimmune diseases such as arthritis. Normally a white blood cell called a regulatory T cell suppresses these self-reactive immune cells. We have identified factors that govern the generation of regulatory T cells. Understanding how these factors work should permit the development of new strategies to combat autoimmune diseases. _

children.name: Expression and secretion of large clostridial toxins from the pathogenic clostridia.

data.scientific_title: Expression and secretion of large clostridial toxins from the pathogenic clostridia.
data.simplified_title: How are large clostridial toxins produced and released from bacterial cells?
data.source_system: The large clostridial toxins are an important family of bacterial virulence factors that includes toxins from many disease-causing clostridial species. Despite their impact on public health, pathogenesis of disease caused by these bacteria is poorly understood. We will analyse how these bacteria regulate the production and secretion of the large toxins, which will give us a better understanding of the mechanisms of disease causation as well as identifying novel common therapeutic targets.

children.name: Novel therapeutic and preventive strategies for Clostridium difficile infections.

data.scientific_title: Novel therapeutic and preventive strategies for Clostridium difficile infections.
data.simplified_title: New ways to treat and prevent nosocomial diarrhoea.
data.source_system: The bacterium Clostridium difficile is the major cause of nosocomial diarrhoea in many countries, including Australia. More virulent isolates have recently emerged, leading to increased incidence and disease severity in many countries. This project will make a major contribution to our understanding of how these bacteria cause disease. Preventive or treatment measures based on these research findings will help to prevent or lessen the severity of any epidemics that occur in Australia.

data.scientific_title: Structural studies on plasminogen
data.simplified_title: Structural studies on plasminogen
data.source_system: Plasmin is a complex enzyme that performs major roles in removal of blood clots, wound healing and in tumor metastasis.  Here we will understand how plasmin function is regulated at the molecular level.  These key insights will be of future use in the development of therapeutics targeting the plasmin system in cancer and clotting diseases.

children.name: SRY: A Risk Factor for Parkinson�s Disease in Men?

data.scientific_title: SRY: A Risk Factor for Parkinson�s Disease in Men?
data.simplified_title: SRY and Parkinson's disease
data.source_system: Parkinson�s disease is a debilitating neurological disorder that affects over 70,000 Australians. This project will test the novel concept that the male sex-determination gene SRY is a risk factor for Parkinson�s disease in men. A potential implication of the work is that it will help explain why men are more susceptible to Parkinson�s disease than women, and may also provide avenues for the development of novel therapeutics for this condition.

children.name: Understanding the role of caudal auditory belt areas in perception of complex sounds

data.scientific_title: Understanding the role of caudal auditory belt areas in perception of complex sounds
data.simplified_title: Understanding the role of different cortical areas in auditory perception
data.source_system: Although the auditory cortex is key to our understanding of several neurological conditions, including language impairments, the functions of many of its areas are still unknown. Using an animal model, we will examine the roles of different auditory areas in separating important sounds from noise. This is a critical role in coordinating our body�s responses to acoustic stimuli. This study will help clarify how these areas contribute to how we normally process sounds, and what deficits are likely to occur if they are damaged.

children.name: Sensory cortex processing changes underlying brain and behaviour deficits caused by traumatic brain injury

data.scientific_title: Sensory cortex processing changes underlying brain and behaviour deficits caused by traumatic brain injury
data.simplified_title: How damage to the brain's processing of sensory input underlies the behaviour deficits caused by brain injury
data.source_system: Traumatic brain injury (TBI) from physical head trauma causes behavior and cognitive deficits. The burden for victims, families and the community is enormous: total life-time expenses in moderate-to-severe TBI are estimated to be $8.6 billion in Australia. We aim to elucidate whether changes in how the brain processes sensory information could underlie TBI-induced deficits in complex behaviour and whether these changes will be ameliorated by the three currently-most-promising treatments for TBI.

children.name: Can Blockade of Leptin Action in the Brain reduce Blood Pressure in Obese Mice?

data.scientific_title: Can Blockade of Leptin Action in the Brain reduce Blood Pressure in Obese Mice?
data.simplified_title: How does obesity cause hypertension?
data.source_system: The aim of these studies is to determine if high leptin levels in obese mammals activate the sympathetic nervous system (SNS), and thereby contribute to pathologically high blood pressure, increased heart rate and diabetes. If so, it may be possible to develop novel therapeutics to acutely improve a patient's metabolic condition, by blocking leptin action. The obese are already insensitive to the anorectic actions of leptin, so blocking leptin would likely have no deleterious consequences.

children.name: Activin mediated endothelial dysfunction: novel therapies for preeclampsia

data.scientific_title: Activin mediated endothelial dysfunction: novel therapies for preeclampsia
data.simplified_title: Novel Treatment for Pre-Eclampsia
data.source_system: Preeclampsia remains a major cause of death of both pregnant women and their babies. The treatment for preeclampsia has not changed in decades. New insights into underlying causes of the disease have offered opportunities for the development of better, more effective treatments. This project aims to test such new therapies in an animal model of the disease with a view to future clinical trials.

children.name: Efficacy of melatonin for sleep disturbance following traumatic brain injury

data.scientific_title: Efficacy of melatonin for sleep disturbance following traumatic brain injury
data.simplified_title: Efficacy of melatonin for sleep disturbance following traumatic brain injury
data.source_system: This randomized controlled trial will evaluate the effectiveness of melatonin, a naturally occurring hormone, in alleviating sleep disturbances in people with traumatic brain injury.  If successful, melatonin therapy could substantially improve the quality of life of individuals with TBI, improving their participation in vocational, leisure and social activities and enhancing their emotional well-being.

children.name: An integrated systems biology approach for the development of new therapeutic strategies for the treatment of high grade glioma

data.scientific_title: An integrated systems biology approach for the development of new therapeutic strategies for the treatment of high grade glioma
data.simplified_title: New therapies for the treatment of brain cancer
data.source_system: Glioma, the most common adult brain cancer, is incurable. Recent advances now allow us to grow glioma cells directly from patients in the laboratory in a way that preserves the features of the original tumor. In this proposal we will systematically analyze such cells using state-of-the-art technologies to identify new processes important to glioma, which in turn should facilitate the identification of innovative therapeutic approaches.

children.name: The SNORE-ASA study:  a Study of Neurocognitive Outcomes, Radiological and retinal Effects of Aspirin in Sleep Apnoea

data.scientific_title: The SNORE-ASA study:  a Study of Neurocognitive Outcomes, Radiological and retinal Effects of Aspirin in Sleep Apnoea
data.simplified_title: SNORE-ASA:  does sleep apnoea cause brain dysfunction by damaging small blood vessels, and can this be prevented with aspirin?
data.source_system: Sleep apnoea is very common in the elderly, but it is uncertain whether it leads to a decline in mental abilities as it can in the middle-aged.  Apart from fatigue, sleep apnoea also causes mental decline by affecting brain blood supply.  This may be preventable with aspirin.  We will track 3,000 healthy elderly for 4 years, after testing for sleep apnoea.  Half will take aspirin.  We predict that mental ability will decline faster with sleep apnoea, and that aspirin will partly reverse this.

children.name: Characterisation of eurl, a novel gene implicated in the etiology of abnormal brain development and intellectual disability

data.scientific_title: Characterisation of eurl, a novel gene implicated in the etiology of abnormal brain development and intellectual disability
data.simplified_title: The role of the novel gene eurl during brain development and in adulthood
data.source_system: Intellectual disability affects around one per cent of Australians, and can arise from genetic abnormalities during fetal life, such as through abnormal regulation of gene expression.  We have identified a novel gene, known as eurl, which controls brain assembly as well as the ability of neurons to form functional connections within the brain.  We will investigate how this novel gene controls brain development, and characterise eurl as a potential therapeutic target for learning and memory.

children.name: The role of scube gene function in hedgehog signal transduction

data.scientific_title: The role of scube gene function in hedgehog signal transduction
data.simplified_title: Scube gene function
data.source_system: The Hedgehog signaling pathway controls development of the early embryo and is one of the most common pathways mutated in human cancer.  Through the use of zebrafish genetics we have identified a new component of this pathway, Scube2 that controls the ability of cells to be activated by Hedgehog signaling. We plan to further investigate how this occurs and design therapeutically relevant peptides based on the scube2 protein that could act as inhibitors of the pathway

children.name: Novel antagonists of the nuclear receptor LRH-1

data.scientific_title: Novel antagonists of the nuclear receptor LRH-1
data.simplified_title: LRH-1 antagonists for cancer drug discovery
data.source_system: LRH-1 is a protein that is inappropriately present in cancers of the breast and other tissues. It causes cancer cells to divide and multiply, and therefore it is important to block its activity. There are, however, no treatments available that block LRH-1. This proposal brings together a team of researchers with broad experience. We will use high throughput technologies to identify and characterize novel LRH-1 inhibitors, and demonstrate their efficacy in reducing the growth of cancer cells.

children.name: Impaired respiratory tolerance in obesity - the link with asthma?

data.scientific_title: Impaired respiratory tolerance in obesity - the link with asthma?
data.simplified_title: The role of diet and obesity on development of asthma
data.source_system: Australia has one of the highest obesity rates in the world, placing a major strain on health budgets.  Obesity increases the risk of numerous diseases, including asthma.  Asthma is prevented in healthy people by the immune system.  This project will investigate whether obesity-related dietary factors and/or gut microbes impair this immune-mediated mechanism.  Outcomes will increase understanding of the effects of diet and obesity on asthma development, and lead to novel asthma therapies.

data.scientific_title: Practitioner Fellowship
data.simplified_title: Practitioner Fellowship
data.source_system: In this Fellowship I will capitalise on my role as Professor of Surgery and Public Health at Monash University, Director of the National Trauma Research Institute, and a surgeon at The Alfred Hospital, to lead a program of research that improves our understanding of what works in trauma care and trauma systems, uses scientific strategies to ensure research makes a difference to practice and policy, and supports further research that seeks to understand how research can best be used to improve injured peoples' lives.

children.name: Decidual-trophoblast interactions critical for optimal pregnancy outcomes

data.scientific_title: Decidual-trophoblast interactions critical for optimal pregnancy outcomes
data.simplified_title: Decidual-trophoblast interactions required for a healthy placenta
data.source_system: This proposal seeks to identify the critical maternal and embryonic placental factors that regulate the formation of a healthy placenta and thus a healthy pregnancy and baby.  Currently there is no way of identifying whether the placenta is forming adequately. The proposed studies are a necessary first step in identifying therapeutic targets for diseases associated with a poorly formed placenta, such as preeclampsia.

children.name: The interferon system in innate immune responses to disease

data.scientific_title: The interferon system in innate immune responses to disease
data.simplified_title: How proteins regulate our early immune response to infection, cancer and inflammatory disease
data.source_system: My research investigates special proteins called cytokines in the body�s first-line defence against infection, inflammation and cancer.  I will characterise how cells respond, the signals that mediate effects, using sophisticated genetic and new computational techniques to manage and analyse data. One focus is a new cytokine we discovered that protects against infections of the reproductive tract _a global health and socio-economic problem affecting 1 billion people.

children.name: Carnitine Palmitoyl Transferase 1 in POMC neurons controls glucose homeostasis and body weight

data.scientific_title: Carnitine Palmitoyl Transferase 1 in POMC neurons controls glucose homeostasis and body weight
data.simplified_title: CPT1 in the brain prevents obesity and diabetes
data.source_system: The brain plays a critical role in body weight gain by balancing appetite-inducing and appetite-suppressing signals. An imbalance in this process causes obesity, promotes diabetes and cardiovascular disease. The aim of this research is to identify how appetite-suppressing brain signals are maintained as a method to prevent obesity progression.

children.name: Allosteric modulation and biased signalling at the calcium-sensing receptor

data.scientific_title: Allosteric modulation and biased signalling at the calcium-sensing receptor
data.simplified_title: Understanding modulation of the calcium-sensing receptor
data.source_system: The calcium-sensing receptor is a major target for the treatment of endocrine and bone disorders. However, the development of drugs for this receptor is challenging due to limited understanding of potential sites of drug interaction and how individual drugs may differentially change signalling from the receptor. This project will address these critical knowledge gaps, which may allow for improved therapeutic outcomes.

children.name: Unlocking the complexities of postnatal brain injury in preterm neonates.

data.scientific_title: Unlocking the complexities of postnatal brain injury in preterm neonates.
data.simplified_title: Identifying the mechanisms of brain injury in preterm neonates.
data.source_system: Brain injury is common in preterm infants and is responsible for significant death or life long disease such as cerebral palsy. Brain injury can occur through many mechanisms however the immediate newborn period is identified as a most vulnerable period. This unique proposal utilises existing expertise and new technologies to advance our understanding of the physiological mechanisms behind the progression of brain injury in preterm neonates.

data.scientific_title: Research Fellowship
data.simplified_title: Research Fellowship
data.source_system: We will apply genome-wide approaches to identify the gene networks that regulate the self-renewal and the differentiation of muscle stem cells and their fusion to muscle fibres. These studies will deliver the first characterisation of the molecules and pathways implicated in these processes, which are essential steps of muscle growth.

children.name: A brief couple-focussed psychoeducational intervention to prevent postnatal mental health problems in women: a cluster randomised trial.

data.scientific_title: A brief couple-focussed psychoeducational intervention to prevent postnatal mental health problems in women: a cluster randomised trial.
data.simplified_title: Prevention of postnatal mental health problems in women
data.source_system: Mental health problems in women after childbirth are of national concern. Interventions to prevent these have had little success. What Were We Thinking (WWWT) is a promising new program for mothers, fathers and newborns. It provides knowledge and skills about soothing and settling babies and enhancing parents� understanding of their changed needs and how to share the workload fairly. This trial will test whether WWWT improves women�s mental health in the first six months of motherhood.

children.name: Mechanisms of Novel TLR9 mediated intraocular inflammation

data.scientific_title: Mechanisms of Novel TLR9 mediated intraocular inflammation
data.simplified_title: Novel mediators of eye inflammation
data.source_system: Corneal opacities and scarring due to microbial and parasitic infections are a major cause of blindness globally. Novel studies in our lab have shown that topical application of bacterial/viral DNA alone to the cornea can cause previously unrecognised inflammation in the retina. Understanding the mechanisms of this retinal inflammation and how to block it may help in the design of novel treatments for a number of blinding conditions.

children.name: Rescuing the last-line therapy colistin against Gram-negative �superbugs�: increasing the therapeutic index by attenuation of nephrotoxicity

data.scientific_title: Rescuing the last-line therapy colistin against Gram-negative �superbugs�: increasing the therapeutic index by attenuation of nephrotoxicity
data.field_of_research: Pharmacology and Pharmaceutical Sciences not elsewhere classified
data.simplified_title: A new approach to maximise colistin effectiveness against Gram-negative �superbugs�: minimising toxicity on kidneys
data.source_system: Antibiotic resistance in Gram-negative �superbugs� is presenting a significant global medical challenge. Colistin (polymyxin E) is increasingly used as the last treatment option even though the current use is suboptimal. Simply increasing the daily dose is not an option due to kidney toxicity. This project focuses on a new approach using antioxidants to ameliorate the potential for colistin-induced kidney toxicity, thereby allowing higher doses to achieve adequate bacterial kill in patients.

children.name: Improving and evaluating the health of mothers and babies

data.scientific_title: Improving and evaluating the health of mothers and babies
data.simplified_title: Improving and evaluating the health of mothers and babies
data.source_system: This research program considers new ways to monitor an unborn baby�s health and to provide better care for childbearing women. Several projects will test the unborn baby�s well being. A new study will consider two forms of cooling treatments to help relieve pain following childbirth. Further research involves studies of the genetics of increased blood pressure in pregnant women and a structured way of looking at existing evidence to consider how well it delivers.

children.name: Neuro-protection in the Preterm Brain - A New Role for Dopamine Therapy?

data.scientific_title: Neuro-protection in the Preterm Brain - A New Role for Dopamine Therapy?
data.field_of_research: Paediatrics and Reproductive Medicine not elsewhere classified
data.simplified_title: Neuro-protection in the Preterm Brain - A New Role for Dopamine Therapy?
data.source_system: Brain injury in premature babies leads to long term adverse outcome. Preliminary data show that dopamine improves brain oxygen. Our study will define effects of dopamine in preventing injury in the immature brain, using animal studies. In immature lambs receiving dopamine, we will test the protective effect of dopamine on brain oxygenation during hypoxia. Outcome will be measured by examining cell injury on lamb brain slices.

children.name: Discovery of New and Better Treatments for Human African Trypanosomiasis

data.scientific_title: Discovery of New and Better Treatments for Human African Trypanosomiasis
data.simplified_title: New Treatments for Sleeping Sickness
data.source_system: Sleeping sickness, or human African trypanosomiasis, is present in 36 countries where there are 60 million people at risk of infection, with 50,000-70,000 new cases and 48,000 deaths per annum. Transmitted by the bite of the tsetse fly, this disease is caused by the protozoan parasite Trypanosoma brucei, and without treatment, death is inevitable. We have discovered some compounds that weakly inhibit T.brucei and the aim of this project is to make them potent enough to become drug candidates.

children.name: Preventing weight gain in young to mid-aged women living in rural communities;a cluster randomised controlled trial

data.scientific_title: Preventing weight gain in young to mid-aged women living in rural communities;a cluster randomised controlled trial
data.simplified_title: Preventing weight gain in young to mid-aged women living in rural communities; cluster randomised controlled trial
data.source_system: Women living in rural communities are gaining weight faster than their urban counterparts. The prevention of weight gain in young rural women presents an opportunity that is urgently needed with potential for major benefits to physical, metabolic and reproductive health. The aim of this project is to prevent weight gain in women of reproductive age living in small rural communities, to improve the preventable risk factors for chronic disease such as poor diet quality and physical activity and to conduct a comprehensive economic evaluation.

children.name: BAFF and its receptors:contribution and therapeutic potential in atherosclerosis

data.scientific_title: BAFF and its receptors:contribution and therapeutic potential in atherosclerosis
data.simplified_title: BAFF in atherosclerosis
data.source_system: Atherosclerosis is an inflammatory reaction to cholesterol in blood vessels. Despite cholesterol-lowering statins, atherosclerosis-based heart attacks and strokes remain a major cause of deaths. Studies of BAFF, a pro-inflammatory molecule can shed new light on the inflammation.  As BAFF blockers are already in clinical trials to treat inflammatory diseases, our study has potential to lead to using BAFF blockers to treat human atherosclerosis.

children.name: A New Class of Anti-Malarial Agents Targetting Apical Membrane Antigen

data.scientific_title: A New Class of Anti-Malarial Agents Targetting Apical Membrane Antigen
data.field_of_research: Biochemistry and Cell Biology not elsewhere classified
data.simplified_title: New Inhibitors that Target a Protein on the Malaria Parasite Surface
data.source_system: Malaria is a major global health problem that imposes a substantial burden on the world�s most vulnerable societies. The invasion of host cells by malaria parasites represents an attractive target for therapeutic intervention, and Apical Membrane Antigen 1 (AMA1) plays an essential role in this process. Agents that bind to a key interaction site on AMA1 prevent host cell invasion and thus represent starting points for the development of a new class of anti-malarial drugs.

children.name: Is mitochondiral STAT3 necessary for K-Ras induced myeloid leukaemias?

data.scientific_title: Is mitochondiral STAT3 necessary for K-Ras induced myeloid leukaemias?
data.simplified_title: Is STAT3 neccessary for myeloid leukaemia?
data.source_system: Myeloid leukaemia (ML) is a family of diseases characterized by the expansion of white blood cells, leading to death from haematopoietic complications. One common mutation that gives a proliferative advantage in ML is in the Ras oncogenes. We recently showed that signal transducer and activator of transcription 3 (STAT3) is necessary for the transforming potential of Ras due to its ability to support the metabolic changes necessary for tumour growth. This research will characterize the STAT3-dependent metabolic changes in ML.

children.name: Diabolic regulation of macrophage cell death pathways by Legionella

data.scientific_title: Diabolic regulation of macrophage cell death pathways by Legionella
data.simplified_title: How intracellular bacteria control macrophage cell death pathways
data.source_system: The bacterial pathogen Legionella causes fatal pneumonia in immuno-compromised humans. Infections depend on a sophisticated secretion machinery that translocates hundreds of proteins into host cells. These proteins subvert several essential defense pathways, including cell death signals. This project will highlight how Legionella interfere with cell death pathways and control the survival of its host cells. These findings will facilitate the development of promising new anti-bacterial agents.

children.name: The role of tissue hypoxia in the evolution of kidney disease

data.scientific_title: The role of tissue hypoxia in the evolution of kidney disease
data.simplified_title: Low oxygen levels in the sick kidney
data.source_system: We will determine how low oxygen levels in the kidney lead to kidney disease. We can now measure the levels of oxygen in kidney tissue in rats 24 hours a day, 7 days a week, in a completely non-invasive way. We will study two common kinds of kidney disease. One, acute kidney injury, can result from administration of contrast agents used in x-ray diagnostic procedures. The other, chronic kidney disease, is common in patients with diabetes or high blood pressure.

children.name: Evaluation and design of therapeutic strategies utilizing zebrafish genetic models of Duchenne Muscular Dystrophy.

data.scientific_title: Evaluation and design of therapeutic strategies utilizing zebrafish genetic models of Duchenne Muscular Dystrophy.
data.simplified_title: Investigating treatments for muscular dystrophy using zebrafish models
data.source_system: Duchenne and Becker Muscular Dystrophy (MD) are allelic muscle wasting conditions arising from mutations in the dystrophin (DMD) gene. We have established zebrafish as a model system in which to determine the mechanistic basis of DMD pathology. We have isolated mutations in the zebrafish dystrophin gene and have determined that Dystrophin-deficient zebrafish accurately model the human condition.  We aim to use the advantages of the zebrafish system to model treatments for muscular dystrophy.

data.scientific_title: Liver disease in HIV-HBV co-infection
data.simplified_title: HIV-HBV co-infection
data.source_system: Morbidity and mortality secondary to liver disease is greatly increased in people co-infected with HIV and HBV compared to those infected with HBV alone. Mortality remains elevated even after treating both viruses. This project will investigate the mechanism of how HIV accelerates liver disease in patients co-infected with HBV. We hypothesize that this occurs by combined effects of HIV and HBV on inflammation in the liver. These studies could potentially lead to new treatments for liver disease.

children.name: Is low dose amitriptyline more effective than placebo in the management of chronic, neuropathic low back pain? A double-blind, randomized, placebo-controlled trial with an economic evaluation

data.scientific_title: Is low dose amitriptyline more effective than placebo in the management of chronic, neuropathic low back pain? A double-blind, randomized, placebo-controlled trial with an economic evaluation
data.simplified_title: Is amitriptyline effective in the management of chronic low back pain?
data.source_system: Chronic low back pain is a major public health problem in Australia. Antidepressants are a common treatment for low back pain, with physicians often prescribing them at low doses for the treatment of pain. However, the use of antidepressants for low back pain is unproven. We aim to perform a clinical trial to examine whether antidepressants are more effective than placebo in reducing pain and disability in patients with chronic low back pain.

children.name: Activation of GDF9 regulates human folliculogenesis

data.scientific_title: Activation of GDF9 regulates human folliculogenesis
data.simplified_title: Activation of GDF9 regulates female fertility
data.source_system: GDF9 is a key regulator of fertility in female mammals, as it controls the process of folliculogenesis. In this grant, we will demonstrate the importance of GDF9 in human folliculogenesis, determine the mechanisms that activate GDF9 and show why aberrant GDF9 activation leads to ovarian disorders. Collectively, the outcomes of this proposal will increase our understanding of the fundamental mechanisms that regulate ovarian folliculogenesis and provide new avenues to manipulate this process.

children.name: Gonadotropin inhibitory hormone (GnIH); a negative regulator of reproduction

data.scientific_title: Gonadotropin inhibitory hormone (GnIH); a negative regulator of reproduction
data.simplified_title: Gonadotropin inhibitory hormone (GnIH); a negative regulator of reproduction
data.source_system: Gonadotropin inhibitory hormone (GnIH) is a short peptide of 8 amino acids that is produced by the brain  and acts in a negative manner on brain and pituitary cells that control reproduction. This project aims to elucidate the role of GnIH in normal physiology and in states of stress and negative metabolic state.
